section.title: Introduction to Discount
section.p: So far, we have assumed interest is paid at the end of each period. This is called interest payable in arrears. Sometimes interest is paid at the beginning of a period, called interest payable in advance. In this case, we call the rate that is used the discount rate and denote it with the variable d.

assemblage.p: ⚠ You should be aware that actuaries use the term discount in the precise sense that we will explore over the next several activities. In business and finance, you will hear discount rate and interest rate used interchangeably. The word discount in that sense is used when using an interest rate to find the present value , said to be "discounting to present value" (as the present value is less than the accumulated value).

introduction.p: Let's start with a simple example from . Suppose Lita Ford borrows 1000 for one year with 10% interest payable in advance.

task.p: The way this works is that the interest is taken out of 1000 and the borrower gets the remainder. What is left? This is A(0).
At the end of the year, Lita has to pay back what was borrowed, both the amount she got and the interest taken out. How much is this? This is A(1).
The discount rate d comes from the following equation: d = \frac{A(1)-A(0)}{A(1)} Calculate Lita Ford's discount rate. What do you notice?

section.p: The formula for d is for an effective discount rate (we will meet the nominal versions later). If time is in years, this is an effective annual discount rate. If time is measured in months, this is an effective monthly discount rate.

introduction.p: For each of the following, find the effective annual discount rate d.

In , we noted that exponential functions are characterized by a constant percentage change. With an effective interest rate \iota, we had \iota = \frac{A(1)-A(0)}{A(0)} and \iota was this percentage rate of change. The base is b = 1+\iota.

task.p: Compare and contrast the formula for \iota and the formula for d. What do you notice?
I like to say that discount is a backwards-looking percentage change. What do I mean by this?

section.p: Let's figure out how we can calculate present and future values when we are given a discount rate d. The following version of an interest rate timeline has the arrows pointing "backwards" to emphasize the backward-looking nature of the percentage change we are working with.

introduction.p: We begin with present value. Suppose we have an amount A(t) at time t and we would like to know A(0).

statement.p: Looking backwards, from A(t) to A(t-1), do you expect percentage increase or decrease? Why?

solution.p: We should have a percentage decrease, since there is less money in the account before interest has accumulated over that year.

statement.p: Since d is the constant percentage change, and is written as a positive percentage, what is the base of our exponential function?
How many factors of our base do we need to multiply by to get back to A(0)?

solution.p: To go from A(t) to A(0), we need to multiply by t factors.

statement.p: Use your answers to write a formula for A(0) given A(t) and an effective discount rate d.
Solve your formula for A(t). This will give us a formula for future value using discount. Typically this formula is written using negative exponents.
